comments.author: Nillie

top_comment.text:
The thing that troubles me with philantropy by billionaires like Bill Gates 
is that giving away their money someway seems like an attempt to legitimate 
themselves and the capitalistic system within people like Bill Gates got so 
rich. I am not trying to make Bill bad, no I think its great that he 
realises that with great wealth comes great responsibility, but he is only 
one person with one opinion and if some other billionaire doesn't share his 
sense of charity, well then fuck you poor people. Philantrophy has to be 
democratised, money has to flow from the richest to the poorest and there 
have to be mechanisms which prevent the creation of a super rich elite, 
which might not want to share its money.
From great wealth comes great responsibility and responsibility has to be 
within the democratic process, not only within a tiny elite.﻿
top_comment.author: MrJoeRedford

Also a problem with taxes is that some rich people might not want to give 
their money to things like leading wars, which is understandable.

All these people in such need of water and then theres THOUSANDS OF IDIOTS 
WASTING WATER doing a "challenge" that is COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY, among 
many other stupid things that people waste water. ﻿
top_comment.author: Brenda H

comments.text:
In most cases water is pumped from the ground, so I fail to see how dumping 
a little water back into the water table is this "massive waste" you people 
always complain about. Launching it into space would be a waste, but the 
Ice Bucket Challenge? Give me a break.
comments.author: OSHbots

comments.text:
Yes, but a bucket of water in America isn't going to do anyone in Ethiopia 
any good.
comments.author: Nolan Thiessen

top_comment.text:
What will actually be done with the money (plan for a water pipe, 
well-digging or another solution)? What was the reason this was not done 
until now? Also, how many more areas in Ethiopia are without access to 
water and how many of them can be taken care of under the 200,000$ project?﻿
top_comment.author: Tom Klinorain

comments.text:
+Tom Klinorain I wonder if part of the reason for areas without reasonable 
access to water being populated is due to a culture that subjugates women 
to the extent that the extremes they need to go to just to get water would 
be considered acceptable.  I don't even go *camping* if there's no running 
water, and I would never allow my family to settle in a place that had no 
easy access to water...  I realize that climate change has made things 
worse, and made some areas dry that previously might have had enough 
water...  Maybe the change was so slow that the people living in these 
places just gradually got used to going further and further for water? 
 (Like a frog in a pot of water being heated so slowly that it doesn't jump 
out.)  Of course it could be the converse, that women are subjugated 
because all their energy goes into survival activities like obtaining water.
comments.author: vancouverlori

comments.text:
I did not assume nothing has been done. I asked what was the plan and what 
prevented it from being executed until now. I'm not blaming water.org in 
fraud or anything, I'm just curious as to what exactly was going on until 
now and where do we go from here.
comments.author: Tom Klinorain

comments.text:
The world is a finite place, with finite resources, with finite time, and 
finite knowledge. You're wrong in assuming nothing has been done til now. 
Visit Water.org to find out just how much HAS been done. Yet, because of 
 finite time, people, resources, and money, everything CANNOT be done 
everywhere right now. It simply is not possible.

However, a particular place in Ethiopia will now join the list of the 
places where an adequate water system can be added and the people there 
educated to maintain this system. Also, John clearly stated that this 
$200,000 was estimated to help about 8000 people. I think it's safe to say 
that this $200,000 isn't the only money that will be invested in the 
towns/villages that need these water systems. People that build and 
maintain these utilities need to be paid in the long term to ensure that 
new infrastructure won't fall into ruin.
comments.author: 10kanutt

comments.text:
Water.org takes a very localized approach. They take a bunch of 
plans/schematics to the community and say "which one best fits your needs 
and how can we build it here?"
comments.author: Nolan Thiessen

top_comment.author: whatsuphotdog

comments.text:
From the website "Prior to installing the new well, we insist on 
village-wide education on good hygiene practices and the importance of 
proper sanitation. Intensive training and motivation seminars on these 
topics are conducted through the project. Experience tells us without good 
hygiene practices and safe sanitation, the health benefits of clean water 
are not sustainable. Regardless of whether a person is drinking clean 
water, without good hygiene habits (such as hand-washing prior to food 
preparation) water-related diseases continue to take their toll."
comments.author: Raymond Smith

comments.text:
They're already doing those things, as John has pointed out in his other 
videos. The biggest issue is that sanitation is almost impossible without a 
clean source of water. Thus, this video and fundraising campaign.

comments.text:
Teaching about sanitation is hard when you have nothing with which to

top_comment.author: Michael Andrew

comments.text: I see what you're saying. Your right.
comments.author: Michael Andrew

comments.text:
It's also very much worth noting that Bill and Melinda Gates have pledged 
to donate 95% of their net worth to charity after they die, and have 
encouraged other wealthy people to do the same. By spearheading campaigns 
like this, the Gates Foundation creates awareness around important global 
issues and encourages a broader engagement with profoundly significant 
problems that affect the developing world specifically. This kind of public 
awareness also increases pressure on other wealthy individuals, charities, 
and corporations that can do more to help.

As far as I can see, the Gates family is doing everything they can to 
promote charity across all groups. Given that they will likely end up doing 
more philanthropic good than anyone else in human history, it's impossible 
to argue that they aren't putting their money where their mouth is.
comments.author: Dan Quick

comments.text:
Wouldn't that be worse? Bill Gates could donate every bit of excess cash he 
has and that would be a pretty big dent in the amount of charity needed but 
then everyone would just see that he spent a billion on charity and that 
their money would be inadequate or unnecessary. Bill Gates wouldn't be able 
to donate that much again because all of his money would be gone and 
everyone else would just forget. Doing it this way where he matches the 
donation gives people more incentive to donate.
comments.author: TheUndefynd1

top_comment.text:
+John Green bravely confronts his (understandable and common) tendency to 
look away from poverty, and he does so in a very public way.  It's a hard 
thing to look at, and it's admirable that John is humble enough to show his 
failures in order to get very real contributions from his followers for 
important problems.

You can help these particular 8000 people in Ethiopia get access to clean 
water by donating at http:www.Water.org .﻿

comments.text:
You wont answer? That's funny, I thought you'd already stopped answering, 
what with not having been able to address any of the points I brought up!
Oh, and sorry, but the duck is already coded. DNA contains all the 
instructions necessary to produce a real live duck. It is thus 
theoretically possible to build the system from scratch. See Craig Ventner 
and the work his team have carried out.
In practice this coding is done by evolution, or gods, or whatever, but the 
code is verifiably there. I've run samples through a DNA sequencing machine 
(I imagine before long most biochemistry degree students will have done 
this), are you really going to refute the fact that an organism can be 
coded? Otherwise what the hell is the code there for?
And if you're going to purport it only constructs the physical body, then 
you're going to have to go back and explain how you're so certain 
conciousness and experience are detached from the physical being. But 
you're not going to are you? Because you cant.

And frankly that is fine. You don't have to be right. But at least have the 
integrity to support your ideas if you're going to spout them. Hell, I 'd 
even do you the service of looking into reading material on your suggestion 
(if it were free), you wouldn't even need to argue the point, you could 
just point me to the facts. But I have a feeling that if any such facts 
existed you'd have used them already, rather than dismissing my arguments 
out-of-hand.
comments.author: PouncingAnt

comments.text:
+PouncingAnt You really should think instead of type.
Can you code a real live duck? with sufficient complexity. Of course not. 
That's how I know. Code doesn't have the expressive power. Now shock me by 
demonstrating that you can actually think and understand. In the deepest of 
silence. When you have the idiotic urge to type new objections, smash your 
fingers with a sledge hammer and think some more. There is still no chance 
I could be wrong. If you write new idiotic objections I wont answer you 
again.
comments.author: Dan Frederiksen

comments.text:
You state that code can be complex beyond your understanding, and also that 
qualia are different from anything we know. What *do* we know about qualia? 
Because if qualia is an unknown and the possible results of an arbitrarily 
complex piece of code are an unknown, there can be no objective certainty 
in the statement that qualia cannot be coded.
Given this, where does your certainty about your categorization of qualia 
and physics come from?
Also, if our subjective experiences of the world are modified by physical 
matter (e.g. alcohol), then how can they be separate from the physical 
processes? Does alcohol then exist in some other unknown dimension where it 
can interact with our non-physical qualia? The idea that our experience is 
a result of the physical wiring of the brain conforms so much better to the 
majority of understanding.
Seriously, your proposition is so full of holes, if this wasn't the 
internet I'd be certain you were pulling my leg.
comments.author: PouncingAnt

comments.text:
+PouncingAnt as a genius I wouldn't claim to know the unknown. I'm saying 
it's impossible irrespective of code complexity. code can be arbitrarily 
complex, way beyond my understanding but qualia such as pain is 
categorically impossible in code. it is a different domain. until you 
actually consider that consciousness and the qualia in it are something 
dramatically different from anything we know, you wont get it. and there is 
zero chance I could be wrong about the significance of qualia. no one could 
ever code pain. no physics process can and it doesn't happen in our bodies 
either. this is a surprise to your world view but it is not wrong. dare to 
think, my simple friend. you might even become smart that way. who knew.
comments.author: Dan Frederiksen

comments.text:
That "all over the place" thinking was humour, more for the entertainment 
of anyone else misguided enough as myself to read down the comments 
section. Anyway, the meat of the argument is based on firm enough science: 
Pain is a transfer of information, and that information is essentially an 
on/off signal (since a neuron can only fire once before having to 
recharge). You could imagine this signal as the argument of a function. 
Yes, its boolean logic, but if you wire up that boolean logic appropriately 
the emergent behaviour can be extremely complicated.
Everything we think and feel is nerve impulses. It is a "Transformation of 
bits. No bit is ever pain", but enough bits chucked into the right 
function, and... Ouch!
All I'm saying is a pain-feeling robot isn't so infeasible. I wonder if you 
can agree on that? More challenging perhaps is the idea that pain, and 
other feelings/emotions are occurring in such a deterministic manner.
I believe you said somewhere that you're a genius AI programmer; if so you 
could probably write some code completely beyond my understanding. 
Likewise, someone (or if you like, God) could flummox you the same way, 
yes? The point, or joke (kind of), is that if we're going to stop believing 
in something "if X happens", then letting X be pain-feeling robots is 
probably not the safest bet in the world... (though, safe enough for a good 
number of decades yet, I imagine).
comments.author: PouncingAnt

comments.text:
+PouncingAnt your 'thinking' is all over the place. Try less haste, more 
somber reflection. Try to understand that executing code is always only 
executing code and nowhere is it pain. A robot can run away from danger 
without feeling fear and retract its hand without feeling pain.
Computation is boolean logic. Transformation of bits. No bit is ever pain.
comments.author: Dan Frederiksen

comments.text:
+Dan Frederiksen
"If you or anyone can make a robot that feels pain..."
Easy! You just program the pain right in!
if(broke_robotfriend){initiate_negative_feedback()}
Any negative feedback mechanism that inhibits damaging other members of its 
group is essentially remorse. The necessity that this has to be "painful" 
is a biased viewpoint owed to our human experience. I'll grant you we're a 
fair way off sentient computers, but given the conditional execution of a 
variety of behaviours (mostly obviously in animals but also in people), in 
a way, we're all robots that feel pain.
I assume you're not going to stop believing? I mean, divine programmer, 
mortal programmer.. No programmer. In our lives it makes damn all 
difference, considering noone has released any bugfixes for a few hundred 
thousand years, right?
comments.author: PouncingAnt

comments.author: Angelina Li

comments.text:
+Angelina Li I hadn't heard of acumen actually - sounds very interesting! I 
definitely agree with you - CSR is indeed great for business, and I did 
outline that in that post I wrote just then. And definitely - the corporate 
world seems cold and unfeeling one but business, at its roots, still exists 
to serve people's needs. And if we got more of them to see benefits in 
human development, not just through CSR (though the benefits of CSR for the 
company are also substantial) but also by seeing the third world as the 
potential markets and places to expand to rather than simply exploit (which 
they can best achieve by expanding people's disposable income by removing 
the barriers that stop them from progressing) - then we'd get a lot more 
human development happening and a greater connection between the business 
world and individuals. 
Indeed, if that happened, and more people found it easier to give and more 
companies marketed the good they were achieving around the world, we'd 
probably influence society a lot more. If businesses could be made to be 
seen as good aspects of society, why couldn't wider society ditch the 
concept of greed is good? Lol that's a bit of a longshot but I reckon it's 
the quickest way we can get global equality. Nice chatting dude - I saw 
your post on the blog's FB page. Always nice meeting others who care so 
much! Keep hitting me up with ideas and spread around my, and your ideas 
with others too!
comments.author: Nikhil Autar

comments.text:
+Nikhil Autar That sounds very interesting! I agree - developing countries 
hold huge potential for nascent markets that are great for businesses as 
well. Have you heard of the organization Acumen? (http://acumen.org/) 
They're a non-profit working with business students and global business 
projects centered around the idea of effective "altruism" principles.

TBH, I feel a lot of what effective altruism is about ought to really align 
with many corporate practices. I feel that CPR is good for business, 
especially if it's done genuinely and is an actual part of your business 
framework. Effective altruism is really all about a results driven approach 
to solving global problems - that's perfect to integrate into business 
models, and good for entrepreneurs who are also seeking a way to impact the 
world. We think of the corporate world as a cold, unfeeling, amoral one - 
IMO that dichotomy is false.

I've looked at your blog, and it seems really interesting! I'm not 
medically oriented but you tell compelling stories and explain ideas in a 
really fascinating way. Liked your Facebook page - I'll keep an eye out for 
new posts ;) Good luck with everything!
comments.author: Angelina Li

comments.text:
+Angelina Li Angelina - indeed I have, and though I agree readily with the 
idea of effectiveness in our efforts (donating to causes that make the 
biggest impact simply makes sense) - I think limiting charity to only 
altruism is a little narrow minded. 
The way we think about charity and aid right now is that of altruism - 
giving without expecting return. It therefore gives off connotations of 
sacrifice.
And when we ask people to give - we only target their compassion, we 
effectively guilt trip them into giving.
We'd get a lot more people willing and able to give if we started making 
charity seem like a win-win. It already is in fact - and those wins aren't 
just limited to the "warm fuzzy feeling" you get from giving - there're 
solid economic benefits in giving too. 
Individuals, governments and businesses can all benefit from helping out 
the third world. As individuals - there are so many ways we can help out 
without that sacrifice. And making this clear to people will definitely get 
more people to give. (You could say people will only give to charities if 
they saw a benefit in it for themselves if this mentality were to shoot off 
- but I don't think it'll stop people from giving because altruism can 
coexist with this. In truth - it'll just allow people to give more)

I've written this all up and effective altruism (and all the stats/evidence 
behind it is there too) on my blog here: 
http://nikhilthegrizzlybear.blogspot.com.au/2014/07/giving-to-charity-is-win-win-businesses.html
And I talk about this - as well as my journey through cancer on the blog's 
facebook page too so check that out if you wanna - very interested in 
chatting about these things =] 
www.facebook.com/musingsofamedstudentpatient
comments.author: Nikhil Autar

comments.text:
+Nikhil Autar Super interesting. Have you heard of a movement in charitable 
thinking called effective altruism? Its basically a movement of people that 
think charity ought to be managed as effectively as possible - i.e. 
greatest results for least amount of money. If you google things like 
GiveWell, 80000 Hours etc. I think you might find some things that are 
interesting to you.

+lawnjart16 That's really interesting! :D I'll go check out the website now 
- sounds like your sister has a pretty cool job, kudos to her!
comments.author: Angelina Li

comments.text:
+Angelina Li  +Anthony VP  My sister works for a waste water treatment 
company (one that makes the flexrakes, etc).  Though not a charity, the 
company is charitable to water causes.  The charities they donate time and 
money to are the following:  charity:water,  water.org, and Water For 
People.  

You both might be interested in the Water for People website.  On Charity 
Navigator it ranks them as a 4 star (highest rating) with 83.2% of 
donations going to the cause.   The reason I mention it to you to is that 
it mentions more on their site than the others about how they work to get 
the people to build and maintain reliable and safe water systems. I think 
what they do are closer in line with what you two (in my opinion) are 
looking for.   It has a case study that I will fully admit I did not read 
it all. Also, it doesn't appear that they are doing work in Ethiopia, but 
other parts of the world.

comments.text:
I totally agree. I just went to the Global Health Conference of 2014 for 
Doctors and medical students and one thing all the amazing speakers 
stressed was that when we try to help out the poor - we should think of the 
best way of accomplishing it. 
Sure we can fly over there and volunteer and maybe make a difference to 10 
- 50 lives by performing surgeries, or help building an orphanage or 
digging a well. Sure we can send money there to fund people to go do that. 
But we'd do it best by doing what you say - setting up systems in "teach 
the teacher" styles which train people to train villagers or people in 
slums or whoever you're trying to help how to deal with their issues with 
the resources they have (indeed, we can loan them small numbers of funds to 
do this themselves). 
This is a summary of the major things I learnt there (part 1 of 3 or 4 - 
the others are just as good) and it's filled with ideas and examples of how 
wwe need to think in order to combat global health challenges.
http://nikhilthegrizzlybear.blogspot.com.au/2014/09/how-to-fix-world-global-health.html

Agree with you 100% - we need to think more systematically about these 
things to make a big difference. And inside that link I explain how you can 
help do that!
comments.author: Nikhil Autar

comments.text:
I get the feeling that pound-for-pound they would rather have a tonne of

comments.text:
+Anthony VP
"Are there no prisons?"
"Plenty of prisons..."
"And the Union workhouses." demanded Scrooge. "Are they still in operation?"
"Both very busy, sir..."
"Those who are badly off must go there."
"Many can't go there; and many would rather die."
"If they would rather die," said Scrooge, "they had better do it, and 
decrease the surplus population."

I mean, have you read "A Christmas Carol?" If so, did you understand that 
line, that it was intended to be a bit of a joke, that we were supposed to 
chuckle at the caricature of a man so barbaric and miserly as to hold that 
view? How can you seriously say that more than 150 years later?

top_comment.text:
So, there is this one thing I was reading few years ago... I would like to 
hear your opinion John (and internet :)).
It was an article in news and it's main point was, that USA and Europe are 
at fault for Africa's horrible state. Reason being - western society came 
in, started to create infrastructure so they could drill for resources 
(oil, ores, etc), started to haul in food and supplies so they could "buy" 
local governments.  
And once they got what they needed, they just left - this however started a 
huge population boom, however Africa wasn't ready for huge amount of people 
that was born, and we have states like Ethiopia. 
Now I'm not sure if this is the case or, but I do think that Africa didn't 
have these problems 200 years ago. 

So my question is.. are we really "helping" them in the long run? ﻿
top_comment.author: Ivan Meress

comments.text:
it's their fault they had the population boom, it's their fault they didn't 
expect the world to advance, 100 years ago 6 billion people didn't exist. 
And now for some odd reason people started having children and multiplying! 
It's barbaric! And now they are exhausting themselves, while at the same 
time having more children, and WORSE, killing eachother over religion and

comments.author: tsohgallik

comments.text:
You almost have it right. A lot of Africa is a complete mess in large part 
to colonization. But it's not because of a population boom. Europeans came 
into Africa, built infrastructure, and used that infrastructure and the 
human manpower available to strip away any sort of wealth they could get 
their hands on. Diamonds. Ivory. Coal. All of that was harvested using 
oppressed African hands to send to Europe. They did nothing to improve the 
lives of Africans. That the railroads and other parts of infrastructure 
could be used by the locals was pure coincidence. As such, the British and 
the French did nothing to improve water availability or agricultural 
practices. In order to create order between Europeans, and to create 
divisions between Africans, the Europeans drew up unnatural borders. 
Suddenly, tribes were split apart, while competing ethnicities were pushed 
together and told they were part of one group. European colonization 
developed a social hierarchy in the colonies where the white man was on 
top, and only the native people who sucked up to them could gain any sort 
of upward mobility. When the Europeans left, they took as many resources as 
they could, and then they left their social hierarchy. The problem was 
that, now, there's nobody at the top to actually make sure things run. You 
couldn't have the suck-ups rule; they represented the oppressors. In any 
case, they weren't sufficiently trained at anything, either. 

To summarize, European colonization
Broke existing boundaries between people, and established new, unnatural 
ones (which caused quite a few civil wars)
stripped away natural wealth of the nations
limited local people's to entrenched poverty
created a social pyramid where everybody is at the bottom
Left with no political plan or powers in place
comments.author: Adnan Ilyas

comments.text:
+kelybigdeal I really don't see how you could be right - there is more than 
one ethnicity, more than one mentality in Africa, just like there is on 
almost every other continent.
I see it all over the world that human culture hinders development. I see 
it in the US, I see it in Europe, I see it in Asia...
I see people being conditioned into being content with their present 
condition. All over the world.
And I don't see how it does not come to mind that a nation can be 
influenced by someone without ever having been invaded by them. The Chinese 
never invaded Europe, yet we play football(soccer), we eat tofu, we use 
fireworks etc.

I really don't see what you are trying to say. The main message I get, and 
I do hope I am reading you wrong, is that Africa is itself at fault for 
being so poor today.
Which is just not true.

comments.text:
Italy tried invading Ethiopia many times and failed, until 1936 when Italy 
crushed Ethiopia's military. They were then ousted in 1941 due to rebels. 
So yeah.
comments.author: Joshua Stoner

comments.text: +Joshua Stoner   Italien Ethiopia
comments.author: Danny Colliflower

comments.text:
Wasn't Ethiopia one of the nations that wasn't under European control? 
Correct me if im wrong but Ethiopia's problems for food and water is mainly 
due to where its located and its own government. Even so, a lot of 
countries benefitted from European intervention such as South Africa and 
much of the north eastern parts of Africa. saying European intervention was 
a detriment to Africa is ignoring the continent as a whole.
comments.author: Joshua Stoner

comments.text:
You're right, our grandfathers and their grandfathers and so on didn't do 
much good to Africa, but also Asia and Sout-America. And still there are 
many companies (Shell and BP, for example) that only seem to care about 
money and in order to make as much money as they can they just dump their 
trash (oil and chemicals etc.) in rivers and oceans, which causes the dirt 
to get into people's and animal's drinking water and you can probably guess 
what comes from that. I know projects like this give you, and me, mixed 
feelings. Because on one hand we are helping the local people and fixing 
what people before us have broken, but on the other hand there are people, 
very powerful people, who just antagonize a lot of the good work that has 
been done. Just like every human problem, this has two sides. And we can 
choose to surrender to the bad side, or we can stand up for our own 
beliefs.
comments.author: Lieselotte Peeters

comments.text:
I honestly think what we are doing now is "undoing" the wrongs we've done. 
Yes, 200 years ago Africa might not have had these problems but 200 years 
ago women couldn't vote, the mentally unhealthy were thrown in prisons and 
the world was a much more disconnected place. Things have changed and it is 
because of how they changed that Africa is poor.
In order for them to be "better" we wouldn't just have to stop donating, 
they would have to keep all the crops they have to feed themselves with no 
outports. Also a big problem with Some parts of Africa is, while the world 
progressed we didn't share this on to them, we let them stay in the state 
they were. It's no longer about getting food and eating it (like 200 years 
ago) there's trade and ties to other countries through the governments that 
we have built.

That's just my humble opinion though.
comments.author: Harlequin Hoatzin

captions.text:
Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday. So when
I was in Ethiopia, I got to talk to this young

girl, who's clinging to her brother, and I
learned that her mom went to Kuwait to work,

and her dad works in the city, so her grandpa
takes care of them.

She told me that she missed her mom and that
worried that her brother might have pneumonia,

and the way his beautiful girl held her brother
just shattered me, and eventually, I looked
away.

In fact, a lot of my footage from Ethiopia
is of me looking away; we drive up to the

hospital past families desperate to get their
loved ones good care, and I look away. I turn

the camera toward preterm babies struggling
to survive under not good enough heat lamps,
and then I turn away.

And then there was this little boy: too thin,
very sick, life-threateningly sick, with diarrhea,

who is the same age as my own son, who had
the same sweet way of getting into a chair

that's too big for him, while outside, his
mother waited nervously for a diagnosis, for

some help, and I looked away. While she waited
to find out if he had malaria, I filmed this
beautiful vista.

Now I think this was partly because even though
these people all gave me permission to film

them, these moments felt very private. But
it was also hard to watch, it's hard to see

kids suffer, and mothers worry, and to feel
powerless before it, and it's hard because

these are problems that I was unaccustomed
to, I mean the poor are voiceless in too much

of our contemporary discourse. This kid's
mom doesn't have a Twitter or a Youtube channel.

And so we don't hear about her challenges
as directly as we hear about others. Maybe

that's part of what makes it easier to look
away too, but regardless, I kept doing it;

I have hours of footage of my camera looking
away. I spent all this time in Ethiopia, and
what I videotaped most was my shoes.

I've talked before about how much there is
to be excited about in Ethiopia - child death

has dropped by more than two thirds in 20
years, and that's amazing! As is the huge

growth in school attendance rates, and the
growing number of college graduates.

But Ethiopia is still one of the poorest countries
in the world. Malnutrition is common, and

almost half of Ethiopians don't have access
to clean water, which is probably why that
boy was so sick in the first place.

So I understand this urge to look away, but
I think to change the world, we must grapple

with it as we find it. I wanna live in a world
where children don't die of diarrhea and malaria,

where they aren't malnourished, where they
can drink clean water. And the world I want

to live in won't come about by me looking
away.

The problem, Hank, is that if we only look
away, it's hard to listen, and it is through

listening that we can learn how to actually
help, rather than just imposing upon others
OUR ideas for what they need.

This woman - a member of the women's health
army - told me that she has to walk miles

twice a week to fill jerrycans with drinking
water, and dirty river water is used for washing.

When I asked her what her community needed
most, she answered immediately: water.

Healthcare worker Abd Al-Kadir said the same,
explaining that it was hard to deliver babies

without water to keep everyone clean. This
healthcare outpost worker, these women, this

grandfather -- they all cited water as among
their most basic needs.

So okay, let's not look away, let's listen.
I talked to water.org and they set up a fundraiser

for the nerdfighter community. All the money
raised will go towards sustainable water solutions

for people in Ethiopia, and if raise a $100,000
in the next 10 days, Bill Gates will personally

match our donation, so every dollar we donate
will count as two, and if reach our goal we
can get safe water to 8,000 people.

Now that's not a solution, Hank. It's not
gonna end poverty or childhood mortality,

but it CAN change the lives of those 8,000
people, so if you can donate, please do at

water.org/johngreen. There's also a link in
the dooblydoo.

Hank, here's to trying to learn to listen,
and not to look away. I'll see you on Friday.
